fields.headline: The prize quiz
fields.bodyText: Adam Hart-Davis began in TV as a researcher for Magnus Pyke, and has since presented many TV and radio shows, including Tomorrow's World, Stardate and What the Romans Did for Us. He has written around 20 books and recently featured on the cover of the Radio Times as one of the Top 40 TV eccentrics. A photographer and a lavatory enthusiast, he is currently working on a new BBC series, What the Past Did for Us. Each week, a different guest quizmaster sets five questions per day, Monday to Friday. Send us your answers to all 25 questions at the end of the week and the first correct entry out of the hat will win a £100 electronic gift card from Borders (www.bordersstores.co.uk) E1 What did Richard Hargreaves invent? a) Spinning Jenny b) Spinning Jimmy c) Spinning Johnny d) Spinning Penny E2 What sort of bike saddle was patented in March 1897 "to protect the organic parts"? a) Hammock b) Pneumatic c) Rubber d) Water-cooled E3 The first pedal cycle was made in 1839 by Kirkpatrick Macmillan in a) England b) Ireland c) Scotland d) Wales E4 The "ordinary" or high bicycle was called by which rude name? a) Boneshaker b) Penny farthing c) Safety bicycle d) Twopence halfpenny E5 Chard in Somerset claims to be home of the world's first a) Burned toast b) Cottage cheese c) Powered flight d) Scrumpy cider Last week's answers to Richard Norton-Taylor's quiz 1 2 3 4 5 A b d a c c B b d c b&d a C d c c b b D d b d a c E a c b b b Winner: Andrew Vevers, Leeds · The full questions and answers are available on the Guardian website: www.theguardian.com/g2 · Entries must reach Prize Quiz, The Guardian, 119 Farringdon Road, London EC1R 3ER by Wednesday September 22. The winner will be notified by September 24. One entry per person. No purchase necessary. The daily online news quiz is at: theguardian.com/quiz
